contentrichtext.text: '''''Sosumi''''' is one of the system sounds introduced in [[Apple Inc.]]'s [[Apple Macintosh|Macintosh]] [[System 7 (Macintosh)|System 7]] [[operating system]] in 1991, an extremely short [[Sampling (music)|sample]] of a [[xylophone]], which gained notoriety in computer folklore as a cheeky response to a long-running ''[[Apple Corps v. Apple Computer]]'' trademark conflict. The sound has been included in all subsequent versions of Mac OS, including [[Mac OS X]]. During the development of [[System 7 (Macintosh)|System 7]], the two Apples concluded a settlement agreement from an earlier dispute when Apple added a sound synthesis chip to its [[Apple IIGS|IIgs]] machine. As a result, Apple Computer was prohibited from using their trademark on "creative works whose principal content is music". When new sounds for System 7 were created, the sounds were reviewed by Apple's legal department who objected that the new sound alert "chime" had a name that was "too musical", under the [[Apple Corps v. Apple Computer|recent settlement]]. The creator of the new sound alerts for System 7, [[Jim Reekes]], had grown frustrated with the legal scrutiny and first [[quip]]ped it should be named "Let It Beep", a pun on The Beatles' "[[Let It Be (song)|Let It Be]]". When someone remarked that that would not pass legal's approval, he remarked "so sue me". After a brief reflection, he resubmitted the sound's name as ''sosumi'' (a [[homophone]] of "so sue me"), telling the legal department that the name was [[Japanese language|Japanese]] and had nothing to do with music.<ref>[http://vimeo.com/9370716 Jim Reekes describing the origins of the sosumi name (Vimeo)]</ref> ''Sosumi'' exists as an [[inside joke]]{{fact|date=September 2012}} on Apple Inc.'s website as the name of a [[Cascading Style Sheets|CSS]] [[typography|typographical]] style used for legal notices such as the copyright notice: <div class="sosumi"> <p class="copyright">Copyright Â© 2012 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.</p> ... == See also == * [[Apple Corps v.
